Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Equipment for the PSI MUSE Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is well known that protons and neutrons are made from constituents, called quarks and gluons. The quarks and gluons give rise to a finite size of the proton, which is about 10,000 times smaller than the size of a single atom. The goal of this project is to measure the size of the proton. An on-going puzzle is that the proton size appears to be different when measured with atomic hydrogen as compared with its counterpart, called muonic-hydrogen, where the electron in a hydrogen atom is replaced by its heavier cousin, the muon. This project will specifically build equipment to be used in an experiment to provide an independent measurement of the proton radius. In addition to the direct scientific goals of the project, the experiments provide students and young scientists experience and training in working in the international collaborations of modern scientific experiments, with state of the art technology.

The seven standard deviation discrepancy between the proton radius measured with muonic hydrogen and with electron-proton scattering may point to physics beyond the standard model of particle physics, or result from novel aspects of conventional physics or from issues in extracting the radius from experimental data. The Muon Scattering Experiment (MUSE) aims to resolve the proton radius puzzle. MUSE uses a mixed pion, muon and electron beam at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. MUSE will determine the proton radius through both muon-proton scattering and electron-proton scattering, in addition to performing these reactions with positive and negative leptons. This not only reduces systematic uncertainties but also provides sensitivity to two-photon exchange contributions that may be responsible for some of the discrepancies seen in earlier experiments. This collaborative project supports the construction of MUSE over the period September 2016 - August 2018. There will also be ongoing testing and commissioning activities at PSI, including a dress rehearsal run with a partial spectrometer in late 2017.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative research proposal was to construct the MUSE experiment, which takes place at the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland. MUSE is designed to investigate the proton radius puzzle, the observation that the proton radius appears to be different when measured with muons vs. when measured with electrons. MUSE was designed to measure the proton charge distribution through scattering of both electrons and muons from protons, and to determine the radius using the measured charge distributions. The experiment also studies some corrections needed to get the radius from the data, by scattering both positively and negatively charged electrons and muons. This collaborative research proposal funded the construction of the MUSE experimental system, which was brought together for a ``dress-rehearsal’’ run in late 2019. While this proposal only funds the MUSE construction, not running, the ultimate goal of the experiment is to test whether leptons and muons interact the same way with the proton, whether there is any novel physics, and to help better determine the proton radius, which is tied to the determination of fundamental physics constants, particularly the Rydberg constant that determines the energy levels of atoms. 

The broader impacts of this work to date are mainly in the training of students and postdocs. The Rutgers personnel involved in the MUSE experiment include 2 postdocs, 3 graduate students, and 10 undergraduates, of whom 1 postdoc, 3 graduate students, and 3 undergraduates worked on the experiment during the time of and related to this grant. Of those working on this grant, the postdoc is now a staff scientist at a laboratory, one graduate student has graduated and is now a postdoc at a university, and one undergraduate has now graduated and started graduate school. The others continue to be at Rutgers and to work on the experiment.
